head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Sergeants

hedline.hl1: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Sergeants

abstract.p: Sgt Richard P Wallace letter, responding to June 7 article Which Man's Army?, in series How Race Is Lived in America, contends article focused on two leaders who failed to take responsibility for their own shortcomings and overlooked Army's success story on race relations

block.p: I have been in the Army for more than 19 years and have served in a variety of positions working with soldiers of every race and religion.
I have been in the Army for more than 19 years and have served in a variety of positions working with soldiers of every race and religion.

You found two leaders who fail to take responsibility for their own shortcomings (front page, June 7). ''I didn't get promoted because I was the wrong color'' or ''I'm being transferred because I am black'' are easy excuses for people afraid to look in the mirror for the real reasons. If you want to see the Army's success story on race relations, you could have found plenty of soldiers -- black, white, Asian and Hispanic -- working together!
RICHARD P. WALLACE Carbondale, Ill., June 8, 2000
The writer is a sergeant first class in the Army ROTC at Southern Illinois University.
